reviewText: There's a huge mistake here.This is not the 1957 version but the 1981 one with LINO VENTURA as VALJAN and MICHEL BOUQUET giving the performance of his career as JAVERT.BOUQUET literally makes you hate his character that always remain stoic whatever the situation.Try to get the FRENCH version or simply forget it if you don't understand the language.Only the DEPARDIEU-MALKOVICH version comes close to it,even if MALKOVICH is miscast.Avoid the 1957 version with GABIN and BLIER.

reviewText: I’ve been very open about the fact that, in all of literature and the storytelling arts, ‘Les Miserables’ is up there as one of the greatest stories ever told.  It is a heartbreaking story filled with misery and the depths of despair, but it is also so epic in scope and so grand in its themes, and the glimmers (yes, they are glimmers) of hope that shine through the cracks in the story make for such a fulfilling experience.  Whether it’s on the stage, the screen or the printed page (no, I haven’t read the book…yet, but I have read the cliff notes in school), this story just gets to you.1958’s film adaptation of this story is a beautifully shot film that gets into the nooks and crannies of this story to expound on these characters (and certain ones better than others) and deliver the heart and soul of the story to the audience.I’ve seen many of the film versions available (still haven’t seen the March version), and I love how each versions seems to highlight a different character, different facet of the story.  Here, the heart of the film kind of centers on the Thenardier family, with Silvia Monfort (as Eponine) delivering a beautiful and complex performance.  Bourvil is also astonishingly good here, filling each scene with the depths of his command of the screen.  I love Jean Gabin very much as an actor, but his take on Valjean is a tad muted.  Valjean can be a canvas for the rest of the world around him to be painted on, but I did expect a little more from Gabin, who is so good in almost everything else.Still, his performance doesn’t really take away from the film, which is filled with so much thanks to the splintered sub-plots that feel so infused to the soul of this film.  One of the better adaptations and truly epic in scope, Jean-Paul Le Chanois should be proud of what he accomplished here.

reviewText: For years I was looking for a quality DVD of this Jean Gabin film - I remember it from Europe as the most famous version of one of the greatest novels in French literature. I love this story of redemption and how it contrasts with the Count of Monte Cristo: the latter focused on revenge, and this one on goodness and dedication to others.On blu-ray it looks fabulous on a 50-60 inch screen. I have seen quite a few blu-ray movies from the 80s which do not look as good as this movie from the 50-s. As a matter of fact, I had no plans of reviewing this movie. Hovewer, since I was so surprised of its image quality, I feel that I have to give Olive Films credit for this release. Great Job!! The movie is in color and audio is French with optional English subtitles.

reviewText: Les Miserables review. 2013Retour, a' la vie!Spoken French; English subtitles. No extras.Let me speak about the Blu Ray release! That's what it's all about anyway; this restored, spit and polish DVD update of the French 1957 movie!I own the standard DVD version of this and even though the package states "restored", it is very low quality viewing, so this is more than a welcome treat to see this film bought back from the edge of the abyss and resurrected to the premiere shining quality of its release date way back in 1957!But it does not come up to par with some other older Blu-Ray releases of its contemporaries and I had to tweak my settings to reach a desired result which I did within seconds!So, for Blu-Ray fans and fans of Les Miserables you'll be happy about your experience too!Now, for my 2 cents {deux sou :} of this version:Even though it's a French production with French stars and actors it pales in comparison to the other versions; French 1934, starring Harry Baur, whom the Nazi's got a hold of at the beginning of the WAR and tortured and killed him; a real "les miserable" story. Raymond Bernard, director and considered the best adaptation; 281 minutes. A Criterion Release.  And a American 1935 flic, staring Fredric March, 108 min.And also 1952, Michael Rennie, 105 min. But both needed to be longer! But both very good flics!As those have the drama factor that is sadly lacking here! And for me it is unfortunate because I'm a big fan of Jean Gabin and wanted to like it so much more than I do! But being a fan I overlook some things too!Perhaps the fault lies with the director playing this French literary monument with "bebe" gants, gloves! I got the impression that the staging was that of a stage play, as even the Paris revolt scenes were played out in an uninspired way. "Watch out soldier don't club that citizen to hard or violently!" seems to be the admonition from the director! And this uninspired pursuit reminds one of high school kids putting on the play!Even so, I do enjoy watching Gabin and the young Reggiani, and Bourvil whose comedy is always lost upon me. And I am very happy to have the Blu-Ray version of a film that was all but lost to us!So even with some detractors I still highly recommend seeing this "restored" classic! Bon chance!

reviewText: This restored Blu-Ray edition from Olive Films is superb in every way. I think this is the finest non-musical version of "Les Miserables". Besides the musical, I have three other versions and none are nearly as comprehensive as this French version. The detail is exceptional and the entire 3 hours and 10 minutes keeps you spellbound. One of the best films of the 1950's.

reviewText: I saw the movie for the first time when I was 10. I am not of the French background. I fell in love with the mistique of France. Partly it happened because of the inspiring characters created by Jean Gabin and other gaints  of the Hexagon. A discovery for everyone who thinks about G-d, destiny,  duty, revolution. To my opinion, that is the only version that wouldn't  have made Victor Hugo livid had he seen it. Jean Gabin will always remain  the only "authorized", canonic Jean Valjean. All other musicals  and shows, no matter how flamboyant and and new agy, are lacking that  "since 1815" cognac-like nobility that Jean Gabin embodies so  well.
summary: The one and only Jean Valjean
Title: N/A

reviewText: I found the reviews for this product to be quite confusing.  I finally ignored one reviewer and ordered it and crossed my fingers.  It is indeed what I was looking for.  This  is a 1957 film of 210 minute length with an international cast that includes Jean Gabin, Daniele Delorme, and Bernard Blier.  Directed by Jean-Paul LeChanois.  What I love about this film is that with 3 1/2 hours there is time to develop the plot so much more fully.  Also, so much was filmed in or around original locations from the book.  I will not debate that strengths and weaknesses of the cast members as it has been a year or two since I have viewed it.  (My VHS copy had become quite poor.)I have seen Les Miserables on stage in Los Angeles and NYC and also an off-Broadway cast that performed it locally.  I also saw an ancient  B&W; film version in a film appreciation class years ago.  I do not recall any miscast actors/tresses in the above 1957 production.  Overall it is excellent.  Yes, the uncle/ward of Marius has some humor written into his part, but he pulls it off well.  Thenardier was rather unsavory and lacked the comic relief of the Broadway version.  The relationship between Marius and Eponine is expounded upon and is quite poignant.  I don't recall much about either Cosette.An extra note---My ancient VHS copy of this had an entirely different cover.  It was distributed by the Bridgestone Group and the only date on it was 1992 for the Sleeve Design.  The cover says this was "filmed entirely in France, near or at the actual places where the events from the story took place."  It mentions French star Jean Gabin and director Jean-Paul Le Chanois and that it is complete and uncut in its' original 210 minute length.  It mentions none of the other cast members.Another note---My new DVD copy says it has been digitally remastered.  I viewed the first part and I surely cannot figure out what has been remastered.  It is a little better copy than my old VHS, that's all.  Maybe they remastered the sound.  Even without pristine viewing conditions I still prefer this version over the others because it is so well done and nearly faithful to the book.Note Three---I have viewed 1952 film with Michael Rennie and he makes an excellent Valjean.  It is shorter and contains several plot variations but is a solid film and I can recommend it without reservation.  It is definitely my number two choice.  The 1935 with Frederic March was was also excellent.  Oddly it is the film with the most brutality.  I would not show it to younger children as the misery and injustice is too intense for them to assimilate well.  Otherwise it was well done, but definitely more melodramatic.

reviewText: This film was disappointing, particularly in the awful dubbing.  The voices bear no resemblance to the stars' actual voices and I was shocked to find that it was not in French with subtitles.  No, it did not say that it was, but I guess I assumed it would be, not being a really well-known foreign film.  The Javert doesn't hold a candle to Charles Laughton's evil portrayal; this guy just looks like a dithery older man who somehow got into a bad situation.  The Cosette also seems like an airhead.  Though the story can hold it's own through almost any treatment, the dubbing was the biggest problem.  It did, however, point up the Dickensian situations and characters.

reviewText: A masterpiece of a movie. The time old story by Victor Hugo of a man, Jean Valjean, who was compelled to steal a loaf of bread, who was compelled to serve a major part of his life in prison. He was eventually released after spending 20 years in prison and the trials and tribulations he had to suffer post release. A long movie, released in French with English sub-titles. In spite of the French language, the movie is understandable for non French speaking audiences. The print is glorious and the sound is distinct. This blu ray version is very well made and worth keeping.

reviewText: Nobody does it better than Gabin. It's refreshing to get a telling that's closer to what Hugo wrote in these days of mindless musicals (horrible me, I don't like the stage musical and I also don't like chocolate-chip cookies: there must be something wrong with me) and short tellings. If you're going to attempt Hugo, at least try to get it right...like this production.

reviewText: Jean Gabin is such a fine actor for this role -- he gives a thoughtful and poignant performance. Despite the 'dated' style of this film, it is perhaps the most honest and powerful version of Les Miserables I've seen on film.  Misery is not just understood in a material sense, but as the degradation of spiritual and moral values, and the poverty of spirit that this creates.This film, like the book, is long (over 3 hrs) and yet (again like the book) it never drags or disappoints.  Victor Hugo would have been pleased, I think, with Jean Gabin as Jean Valjean, and surely any lover of this fine novel would be as well.  I highly recommend this film - especially for use in high school and college classes, for Le Chanois has directed a marvelous production from beginning to end.  I'd give it 10 stars if I could._____________________Since there is no product overview, and since this film is often confused with other versions, here is a formal description:Les Miserables [VHS] (1957) -  A Franco-Italian production.Inspiring and rarely seen rendition of Victor Hugo's classic novel, with Jean Gabin as Jean Valjean, a petty thief who strives desperately to put his past behind him while a relentless lawman pursues him. Daniele Delorme, Bernard Blier also star. 210 min. Dubbed in English.
summary: This film is true to the novel that inspired it - I give it 10 stars!
